title: Evidence-Based Injury Prevention Framework
content:
**Injury Risk Factors**

*Modifiable Risk Factors:*
- Training load errors (too much, too soon) - BIGGEST factor
- Inadequate recovery between sessions
- Muscle weakness or imbalances
- Poor movement quality or technique
- Inadequate warm-up
- Previous injury (increases re-injury risk 2-6×)
- Sleep deprivation (<7 hours)
- Psychological stress
- Nutritional deficiencies (especially energy, calcium, vitamin D)

*Non-Modifiable Risk Factors:*
- Age (masters athletes have longer recovery needs)
- Sex (female athletes higher ACL risk, stress fracture risk)
- Anatomical factors (leg length discrepancy, Q-angle)
- Prior injury history

**Training Load Management**

*ACWR (Acute:Chronic Workload Ratio):*
- Calculate: This week's load / 4-week rolling average
- Safe zone: 0.8-1.3
- Danger zone: >1.5 (significantly elevated injury risk)
- Also risky: <0.8 (undertrained for demands)

*Progression Rules:*
- Maximum weekly increase: 10% (5% for injury-prone athletes)
- After illness/break: Return at 50% and rebuild over 2-4 weeks
- New activity: Start very conservatively regardless of fitness
- High-risk periods: Weeks 2-4 after volume/intensity increase

**Strength Training for Injury Prevention**

*Evidence Base:*
- Strength training reduces overuse injuries by up to 50% (Lauersen et al., 2014)
- Most effective intervention we have
- Eccentric strength particularly protective

*Key Areas by Sport:*

Running:
- Hip abductors/external rotators (glute med, glute max)
- Single-leg strength (addresses bilateral deficits)
- Calf complex (soleus and gastrocnemius)
- Core stability (anti-rotation, anti-extension)

Cycling:
- Quadriceps and hamstring balance
- Hip stability
- Core endurance
- Upper back (for position maintenance)

Swimming:
- Rotator cuff and shoulder stability
- Scapular control
- Core rotation stability
- Lat and back strength balance

**Mobility and Movement Quality**

*Key Areas to Maintain:*
- Hip flexor length (tight from sitting and cycling)
- Ankle dorsiflexion (critical for running and squatting)
- Thoracic rotation (swimming, running efficiency)
- Hip internal/external rotation

*Daily Mobility Protocol (10-15 min):*
- Hip 90/90 stretch: 60 sec each side
- Couch stretch (hip flexor): 60 sec each side
- World's greatest stretch: 5 each side
- Cat-cow: 10 reps
- Thread the needle: 5 each side

**Pre-Hab Exercises**

*Running-Specific:*
- Single-leg deadlift: 2×10 each leg
- Clamshells: 2×15 each side
- Single-leg calf raises: 2×15 each leg
- Side plank: 2×30 sec each side

*Cycling-Specific:*
- Goblet squats: 2×15
- Nordic hamstring curl (or Romanian deadlift): 2×8
- Dead bugs: 2×10 each side
- Glute bridges: 2×15

*Swimming-Specific:*
- YTW raises: 2×10 each position
- External rotation: 2×15 each arm
- Scapular push-ups: 2×15
- Prone swimmers: 2×10

title: Running Injury Diagnosis and Management
content:
**Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome (Runner's Knee)**

*Presentation:*
- Pain around or behind kneecap
- Worse: Stairs, hills, prolonged sitting, squatting
- Better: Rest, keeping leg straight

*Causes:*
- Weak hip abductors (glute med)
- Weak quadriceps (especially VMO)
- Overpronation
- Training errors (volume increase)

*Management Protocol:*

Acute (Week 1-2):
- Reduce running volume 50% or more
- Avoid aggravating activities (stairs, squats)
- Ice after activity if swollen
- Begin hip strengthening

Rehab (Week 2-6):
- Hip abductor strengthening: Clamshells, side-lying leg raises, monster walks
- Quad strengthening: Wall sits, terminal knee extension, step-downs
- Gradual return to running: Pain-free test runs first

Return to Running:
- Start at 50% volume
- No hills initially
- Progress 10% weekly if pain-free

**IT Band Syndrome**

*Presentation:*
- Sharp pain on outside of knee (lateral femoral epicondyle)
- Typically starts after 10-20 minutes of running
- Worse: Downhill, slower paces, cambered roads

*Causes:*
- Weak hip abductors
- Sudden volume increase
- Excessive crossover gait
- Worn shoes

*Management Protocol:*

Acute:
- Stop running temporarily
- Foam rolling (above and below, not directly on painful area)
- Ice
- Cross-train (cycling often tolerated)

Rehab:
- Heavy emphasis on hip abductor strength
- Side-lying leg raises: 3×15
- Single-leg deadlifts: 3×10
- Monster walks with band: 3×15 each direction
- Gait retraining: Wider step width, avoid crossover

Return:
- Avoid downhill and cambered surfaces initially
- Gradual mileage progression
- Continue hip work indefinitely

**Plantar Fasciitis**

*Presentation:*
- Heel pain, worst with first steps in morning
- Improves with movement, may worsen later in day
- Tender on medial heel

*Causes:*
- Tight calf complex
- Weak intrinsic foot muscles
- Rapid volume increase
- Unsupportive footwear
- High BMI

*Management Protocol:*

Acute:
- Calf stretching: 3×30 sec, 3× daily (both straight and bent knee)
- Frozen water bottle rolling: 10 min, 2× daily
- Supportive footwear at all times
- Taping or arch support if helpful

Rehab:
- Eccentric calf raises: 3×15, 2× daily
- Intrinsic foot strengthening: Towel scrunches, marble pickups
- Single-leg balance: 3×30 sec each leg

Timeline:
- Often 6-12 weeks for resolution
- May need to reduce running but not necessarily stop
- Night splint if morning pain persists

**Achilles Tendinopathy**

*Presentation:*
- Pain in Achilles tendon (insertional or midportion)
- Morning stiffness
- Pain with walking/running, may warm up then worsen

*Management Protocol:*

Acute:
- Do not completely rest (mild loading promotes healing)
- Temporary heel lift in shoes
- Reduce running intensity (can often continue at lower volume)

Rehab (Alfredson Protocol or Modified):
- Heavy slow resistance eccentric/concentric:
- Straight knee: 3×15, twice daily
- Bent knee: 3×15, twice daily
- Progress load over 12 weeks
- Expect mild discomfort during exercise (3-4/10 acceptable)

Timeline:
- 12-24 weeks for full resolution typical
- Can run through if pain <5/10 and improves within 24 hours

**Stress Fractures**

*Presentation:*
- Localized bone pain
- Worse with impact, may hurt at rest in advanced cases
- Point tender over bone
- Common sites: Metatarsals, tibia, fibula, femur, pelvis

*Red Flags (High-Risk Fractures - Require Immediate Referral):*
- Femoral neck
- Anterior tibia
- Navicular
- Sesamoids
- Any with visible swelling or inability to bear weight

*Management:*
- Imaging: X-ray (may miss early), MRI (gold standard)
- Non-weight bearing for high-risk fractures
- Reduced weight-bearing for lower-risk (metatarsal, fibula)
- Timeline: 6-12 weeks typically
- Address root causes: Training error, nutrition, bone density, biomechanics

*Return to Running:*
- Pain-free walking first
- Then: Walk-jog protocol over 2-4 weeks
- Gradual return: 50% volume, flat surfaces, soft surfaces

title: Return to Training Protocols After Injury
content:
**Principles of Return to Training**

*Phase Progression Criteria:*
- Pain: Must be <3/10 to progress, no worsening during or after
- Function: Can perform current phase without compensation
- Confidence: Psychologically ready for next phase
- Time: Minimum tissue healing time met

*General Timeline by Tissue Type:*
- Muscle strain: 2-8 weeks depending on grade
- Tendinopathy: 12-24 weeks (can train through with modification)
- Stress fracture: 6-12 weeks non-impact, then gradual return
- Ligament sprain: 2-12 weeks depending on grade
- Bone fracture: 6-12 weeks minimum

**Running Return Protocol (General)**

*Phase 1: Baseline (Week 1):*
- Walk 30 min daily, pain-free
- Strength training (non-aggravating)
- Cross-training (if tolerated)

*Phase 2: Walk-Jog (Week 2-3):*
- Day 1: 5 min walk / 1 min jog × 6 (30 min total)
- Progress by adding 1 min jog, removing 1 min walk every other session
- Target: Continuous 20-minute jog by end
- Frequency: Every other day

*Phase 3: Return to Running (Week 4-6):*
- Week 4: 50% of pre-injury weekly mileage
- Week 5: 60%
- Week 6: 70%
- All easy pace initially
- Continue strength work

*Phase 4: Return to Full Training (Week 7+):*
- Week 7-8: 80-90% volume, can add short tempo
- Week 9-10: 100% volume, gradual intensity return
- Week 12+: Return to intervals if pain-free

**Cycling Return Protocol**

*Phase 1: Baseline:*
- Stationary bike, very easy: 15-20 min
- Low resistance, comfortable position
- Progress duration before intensity

*Phase 2: Volume:*
- Outdoor riding (if balance/control safe)
- Easy terrain, no hills
- Build to 50% of normal duration

*Phase 3: Terrain:*
- Add varied terrain
- Low intensity on hills
- Build to 75% of normal volume

*Phase 4: Intensity:*
- Add tempo blocks
- Then threshold
- Then VO2max work
- Full return by week 6-8 typically

**Swimming Return Protocol**

*Phase 1: Baseline:*
- Kick-only (if shoulder injury)
- Pull-only with buoy (if lower body)
- Easy, short duration

*Phase 2: Technique:*
- Full stroke at easy effort
- Focus on pain-free technique
- Drill work acceptable

*Phase 3: Volume:*
- Build distance gradually
- No sprints or high-intensity yet

*Phase 4: Intensity:*
- Add threshold swimming
- Then race-pace work
- Full return by week 4-6 for most injuries

**Monitoring During Return**

*Pain Response:*
- Pre-exercise: Should be <2/10
- During exercise: Should be <3/10 and not increasing
- 24 hours post: Should not be worse than baseline
- If any are violated: Back off to previous phase

*Warning Signs to Stop:*
- Sharp pain
- Pain that alters movement pattern
- Swelling returning
- Pain that worsens during session
- Pain lasting >24 hours post-exercise

*Red Flags (Seek Medical Attention):*
- Sudden severe pain
- Inability to bear weight
- Visible deformity
- Significant swelling
- Numbness or tingling
- Pain that wakes you from sleep

title: Cycling Injuries and Bike Fit Issues
content:
**Position-Related Pain: Diagnosis and Fix**

*Anterior Knee Pain (Front):*

Causes:
- Saddle too low
- Saddle too far forward
- Cranks too long
- Cleats too far forward

Fixes:
- Raise saddle 5-10mm at a time
- Move saddle back slightly
- Check: With crank at 3 o'clock, knee should be over pedal axle
- Cleat position: Ball of foot over or slightly behind axle

*Posterior Knee Pain (Back):*

Causes:
- Saddle too high
- Saddle too far back
- Overextension at bottom of stroke

Fixes:
- Lower saddle 5-10mm
- Move saddle forward
- Check: 25-30 degree knee bend at bottom of stroke

*Lateral Knee Pain (Outside):*

Causes:
- Cleat rotation wrong
- Insufficient float in cleats
- Feet forced into unnatural position
- IT band issues

Fixes:
- Assess natural foot angle, match cleat rotation
- Use cleats with more float (4.5-6+ degrees)
- Consider wedges if foot canting needed
- Strengthen hip abductors

**Lower Back Pain**

Causes:
- Reach too long (stem/bars too far)
- Position too aggressive (saddle to bar drop excessive)
- Weak core/hip flexors
- Poor hip flexibility

Fixes:
- Shorter stem or higher bars
- Less saddle-to-handlebar drop
- Core strengthening program
- Hip flexor stretching
- Consider bike fit reassessment

**Neck and Shoulder Pain**

Causes:
- Reach too long
- Bars too low
- Elbows locked
- Death grip on bars

Fixes:
- Shorter reach (stem, frame)
- Higher bars (spacers, stem angle)
- Soften elbows, relax grip
- Frequent position changes during rides

**Saddle Discomfort**

*Types:*
- Pressure/numbness (perineal)
- Chafing/skin irritation
- Sit bone pain

*Solutions:*

Pressure/Numbness:
- Saddle with cutout or channel
- Adjust saddle tilt (usually level to slight nose down)
- Check saddle height (too high increases pressure)
- Wider saddle may help some

Chafing:
- Quality chamois cream
- Well-fitted bib shorts (no seams in wrong places)
- Gradual increase in saddle time
- Good hygiene (shower promptly, clean shorts)

Sit Bone Pain:
- Measure sit bones, match saddle width
- Break in period for new saddles
- May need firmer or softer saddle (individual)
- Padded shorts more effective than saddle padding

**Hand Numbness (Handlebar Palsy)**

Causes:
- Ulnar nerve compression
- Too much weight on hands
- Bars at wrong angle
- Poor fit (reach too long)

Fixes:
- Padded gloves
- Ergonomic bar tape
- Adjust position to reduce hand pressure
- Frequently change hand positions
- Strengthen core (reduces need to support weight on hands)

**Professional Bike Fit**

*When to Get One:*
- New bike purchase
- Persistent pain despite self-adjustment
- After significant injury
- Performance plateau possibly related to position
- Every 1-2 years if racing seriously

*What to Expect:*
- Interview about goals, injuries, flexibility
- Flexibility and strength assessment
- Dynamic fit on bike with video
- Cleat and saddle pressure mapping (advanced fits)
- Multiple iterations and follow-up

*Cost: $150-400, worth investment for serious cyclists*
